Detailed Description

A logging class (what more need be said?).

This is a class used to aid in the output of information. It acts as sort of a merge between c output and c++ output. It's mostly based off of the old printf style, like with ostreams, you don't need to specify data type. It also supports a small set of string replacement tags for easy inserting of time, class names, line numbers, etc... Other features include built in indentation, leveled output (trace, debug, etc...), and outputing to a file or the console. The debug level may be set at compile time allowing certain messages to be completely removed from the code resulting in absolutely zero performance loss (the downside to this is the necessity of macros).

Like the old printf output, this logger will make use of format strings and % deliniated wild cards. The difference is that instead of just marking variable insertion, tags will also mark special replacements. Here is a list of supported values:

f - File t - Time c - Class l - Line

Variables will be supported using numerics to index into the passed variables. Here is an example out how to output with this library, as well as equivilent code using the conventional C and C++ methods:

int a = 1, b = 5; Debug("[%t] %2 * %1 = %2", a, b); Debug("[%t]" << b << "*" << a << "=" << b); printf("[%s]%i * %i = %i\n", getTimeString(), b, a, b); cout << "[" << getTimeString() << "] " << b << " * " << a << " = " << b << endl;

All three will output the following (assuming it is 6:30PM): [18:30] 5 * 1 = 5

Author:
Brent Wilson

Member Enumeration Documentation

enum Logger::LogType

LogType enumerates the different log levels available to the system.

Enumerator:
TraceMessage  Used for tracing the codepath.
DebugMessage  Used to help find errors in the code.
InfoMessage  Used for generic information that would be helpful.
WarningMessage  Used when questionable behavior arises.
ErrorMessage  Used to log errors that could have major repercussions.
NoOutput  Used simply to shut off all output.

Member Function Documentation

void Logger::setPretext ( const string &  text  ) 

Sets the pretext string that is printed as the object is being created. Often this will make use of the various built in replacements like t and c.

Parameters:
text The text to print out during object construction.

void Logger::setIndentLevel ( int  level  ) 

Sets an indent level for output. By setting the indent level, leading whitespace is added to all output to aid in clarity.

Parameters:
level The number of indentations to place before output.
See also:
setIndentSize

void Logger::setIndentSize ( int  size  ) 

Sets the number of spaces per indentation.

Parameters:
size The number of spaces in a single indentation.

void Logger::setAbortOnError ( bool  abort  ) 

Sets the a parameter that determines if LogType 'Error' messages will cause the program to abort once the message has been printed out. This may make debugging certain errors easier.

Parameters:
abort The new value to determine if errors result in an abort.

void Logger::setLogTarget ( const string &  filename  ) 

This function is used to determine where program output is directed. Output can be sent to a log file or standard out.

Parameters:
filename Sets the file to log to. If this value is NULL, logging will go to standard out.

void Logger::setLogLevel ( LogType  level  ) 

The log level may be set at both compile and run time. When set at compile time, certain log messages are not even compiled into the code, thus the compile level acts as a hard cap for the ammount of output whereas this acts as a soft cap.

Parameters:
level The minimum level of output to actually log.

void Logger::clearLogFile (  ) 

This will delete the old log file.

void Logger::usePrintfFormatting ( bool  useOld  ) 

Sets a flag the decides if the old printf wildcard notation should be used. This means all of the special tags (time, file, etc...) will be unusable, as will the special variable notation (1, 2, etc...). All log functions will act just like printf (want more info? man printf).

Parameters:
useOld Determines if printf notation should be used.
